Details of, or auxiliary devices for, ticket-issuing machines

for avoiding incorrect action of the machine
indicating when ticket supply is exhausted
allowing manual writing on the tickets
Holders providing direct manual access to the tickets

CPC-specific-text.text: operating mechanically

title-part.text: for indicating fare or state of hire

CPC-specific-text.text: with indicating means on the outside of the vehicle

title-part.text: Arrangements or apparatus for collecting fares, tolls or entrance fees at one or more control points

reference.text: handling coins or paper currency G07D; apparatus for vending or hiring articles or services activated by coins, credit cards, paper currency or the like G07F7/00 , G07F17/00

note.note-paragraph:
Data processing aspects of payment systems or protocols relating to toll, entrance fee or fare collection, e.g. in road pricing or congestion charging, are also classified in G06Q20/00 .
Notes
This group covers also:
- car rental systems;
- systems for reserving and using access tickets, e.g. check-in systems

title-part.text: taking into account a variable factor such as distance or time, e.g. for passenger transport, parking systems or car rental systems

reference.text: G07B15/06 takes precedence; taximeters G07B13/00 ; parking meters per se G07F17/24 ;

CPC-specific-text.text: car rental systems per se G07B15/00

title-part.text: comprising devices to free a barrier, turnstile, or the like

reference.text: turnstiles with registering means G07C9/02 ; coin-freed aspects G07F17/00

title-part.text: Arrangements for road pricing or congestion charging of vehicles or vehicle users, e.g. automatic toll systems

note.note-paragraph: This group covers the identification or tracking of vehicles or vehicle users for the purpose of road pricing or congestion charging, which means that vehicles or vehicle users are not necessarily channelled through fixed control points, e.g. toll booths or overhead gantries, but may be detected at a number of places when they travel in normal fashion in a pre-defined locality, e.g. a defined area in a city centre or an expressway, and where the information so generated is then used to determine a charge to be paid

CPC-specific-text.text: using wireless information transmission between the vehicle and a fixed station

reference.text: identification of vehicles G08G

reference.text: printing aspects B41

note.note-paragraph:
References listed below indicate CPC places which could also be of interest when carrying out a search in respect of the subject matter covered by the preceding group:
- secret or secure communication H04L9/00
- mechanisms actuated by objects other thancoins
to free or to actuate vending, hiring, coin or
paper currency dispensing or refunding apparatus
for cashless transactions only G07F7/10F6
- access-control involving the use of a pass in
combination with an identity-check of the pass-
holder by means of personal physical data, e.g.
characteristic facial curves, hand geometry,
voice spectrum, fingerprints G07C9/00
- methods or arrangements for reading or
recognising printed or written characters or for
recognising patterns G06K9/00
- random or pseudo-random generators G06F7/58
- circuits generating pulses having a
predetermined statistical distribution H03K3/84
- multiple service credit cards with protecting
memory zones G07F7/10D10M
- security arrangements for protecting computers or computer systems against unauthorised activity G06F21/00
- record carriers with conductive marks and
special arrangements for circuits, e.g. for
protecting identification code in memory G06K19/073
- error detection and error correction G06F11/00
- coding, decoding or code conversion, for error
detection or error correction H03M13/00 ]

title-part.text: using specific cryptographic algorithms or functions
Symmetric, secret-key algorithms, e.g. DES, RC2, RC4, IDEA, Skipjack, CAST, AES
Asymmetric, public-key algorithms, e.g. RSA, Elgamal
Digital signature, e.g. DSA, DSS, ECDSA, ESIGN

reference.text: Message Authentication Code

title-part.text: Hash function, e.g. MD5, MD2, SHA
using timestamps, i.e. recording time in message
Continuous communication, e.g. answer within a limited time period
Postal data, e.g. postage, address, sender, machine ID, vendor
Key storage, e.g. escrowing by trusted third party
using look-up tables, also called master tables with pointers
Key verification, e.g. by using trusted party

reference.text: Error Detection Codes

title-part.text: Cryptographic modules, e.g. a PC encryption board

US Postal Service
